awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Multiscale Study of  Active Cellular Matter: Simulation, Modeling, and Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Active cellular matter is the basis of novel synthetic active fluids made of mixtures of suspended cytoskeletal filaments and molecular motors. By consuming chemical fuel, the molecular motors (e.g., kinesins) can bind to and create actively moving crosslinks between the biofilaments (e.g., microtubules) to drive their relative motion, which leads to large-scale collective motions in the filament/motor mixture through hydrodynamic coupling. Synthetic active suspensions made of small numbers of components reveal how higher-order aspects of assembly and organization are built in living cells. These systems also present new challenges to our understanding, design, and analysis of materials, and have the potential to provide valuable new technologies such as autonomously moving and self-healing materials.

In this work, the investigators study active cellular matter composed of microtubules and molecular motors through multiscale methods, and tightly coupled modeling, analysis, and simulation. The project aims to understand the fundamental interactions underlying stress generation within bundles of rigid/flexible biofilaments that undergo dynamic instability, as well as the nonlinear dynamics and hierarchical pattern formation in large-scale collective motions. The project will also predict key material properties including its coherent structures, local heterogeneity, time- and length-scales, and material rheology. To resolve the physics at different length- and time-scales, several methods will be developed and integrated: (1) microtubule-motor interactions will be simulated using a kinetic Monte Carlo method; (2) the hydrodynamic interactions between objects of various shapes will be modeled using a nonlocal slender body/boundary integral method, together with fast summation methods; (3) a pseudo-spectral method will be implemented to simulate the collective motion through a continuous active liquid-crystal type model.

por.por_cntn:
The innards of eukaryotic cells -- humans are eukaryotes -- are active places, with many their fundamental processes, like cell division and gene regulation, driven by molecular machines working on filamentous proteins. In trying to understand these living systems, we have developed models of them as complex materials driven and rearranged by energy-consuming microscopic motors.

The chromatin fiber is the functional form of DNA within the nucleus, and there is a plethora of nuclear machines at work upon it, transcribing, replicating, and remodeling its DNA. In one project, we have developed an active polymer model for the dynamics of chromatin in the eukaryotic nucleus. This was motivated by recent studies showing that the nucleus is highly dynamic and that chromatin shows correlated displacements on the time-scales of seconds and length-scales of microns. We found that "extensile" motors (basically, molecular machines that stretch the fiber) acting upon the chromatin fiber and the surrounding nucleoplasm (the fluid inside the nucleus) gave rise to self-organizing and long-ranged rearrangements of the strand, in good agreement with experimental displacement studies. We predicted that underlying this agreement is the development of activity-induced nematic ordering, or alignment, of the chromatin fiber.

Another important organelle in the eukaryotic cell is the spindle apparatus, which assembles to orchestrate the segregation of chromasomes during cell division. The spindle is made up of many stiff biopolymers -- microtubules -- acted upon by a plethora of molecular motors and cross-linkers. Defects in spindle assembly and function underly many types of human disease such as cancer. We have been building theoretical and computational tools to help us understand the self-assembly and internal mechanics of the spindle.

Firstly, we have developed a very substantial code-base for the simulation of microtubule/motor-protein systems both in isolation and in environments modeling the interiors of cells. Recent progress has been the development of methods for the efficient and accurate handling of microtubule-microtubule collisions, and on methods for motor binding and unbinding that respect basic tenets of statistical physics. This has recently been applied to reproduce experimental results of the contraction, alignment, and buckling of in vitro systems of microtubules and molecular motors. This code-base allows for confinement and the computation of background fluid flows induced by material motion.

Secondly, and most recently, we have developed a new mathematical theory for the motion of highly crosslinked microtubules moving under the action of molecular motors. This multiscale theory is based on a conception of microscopic motor activity and cross-linking, and incorporates many-body interactions to yield differential equations for the large scale behavior of the microtubule/motor mixture. It shows that heavy cross-linking leads to a viscous response in the network and yields that microtubule speeds through polarity sorting are independent of the local network polarity (the statistical average of microtubule direction). This latter feature has been observed in real spindles, and is unexplained by earlier theories. In somewhat earlier work we developed a model of microtubule branched nucleation and regulation that explained the sharp boundaries observed in spindles.

Lastly, we developed new methods for simulating and analyzing the dynamics of immersed and driven fiber assemblies, such as those that arise in eukaryotic cells.  While specialized numerical methods have been developed to study fiber-fluid systems, they become infeasible when there are many, rather than a few, fibers present. We derived a continuum model, based on local-slender body theory for elastic fibers immersed in a viscous Newtonian fluid. It takes the form of a anisotropic Brinkman equation whose skeletal drag is coupled to elastic forces. We used this approach to study the rheology of microtubules under oscillatory shear, and extended it to study a simple model of waves and instabilities on beds of actuated fibers, as a model for ciliary beds and microtubule-driven flows in the Drosophila embryo.
